results.name: a(n) = smallest odd k such that either k*2^n - 1 or k*2^n + 1 is prime.
comment: As N increases, (Sum_{n=1..N} a(n)) / (Sum_{n=1..N} n) tends to log(2)/2 as seen by plotting data; this is consistent with the prime number theorem as the probability that x*2^n - 1 and x*2^n + 1 are prime is ~ 2/(n*log(2)) if n is great enough, so after n*log(2)/2 try (n*log(2)/2)*(2/n*log(2))=1.
For n=1 to 10000, a(n)/n is always < 3.2.
link: Pierre CAMI, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
mathematica: Table[k = 1; While[Nor @@ Map[PrimeQ, k*2^n + {-1, 1}], k += 2]; k, {n, 77}] (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Apr 02 2017 *)
program: (PARI) a(n) = my(k=1); while (!isprime(k*2^n-1) && !isprime(k*2^n+1), k+=2); k; \\ _Michel Marcus_, Mar 31 2017
